description: The LTQ linear ion trap can acquire ions across a standard mass range of m/z 50–2000, with optional extended settings that push the lower boundary to ~15 m/z and the upper boundary to 4000 m/z for specialized workflows.
prompt: Provide the supported mass-to-charge (m/z) range for the Thermo Electron Finnigan LTQ linear ion trap mass spectrometer, including standard and any extended operating modes. Return JSON with keys: min_mz, max_mz, extended_modes (list of objects with mode and range).

FAQs.question: What is the purpose of this parameter?
FAQs.answer: It defines the smallest and largest m/z values the instrument can detect, determining which analytes can be measured.

FAQs.question: How does this parameter affect the model's performance?
FAQs.answer: A wider mass range enables detection of diverse analytes but may trade off with resolution and scan speed at the extremes.

FAQs.question: What are the default values for this parameter?
FAQs.answer: Default full-scan range is m/z 50–2000.

FAQs.question: Can this parameter be adjusted during acquisition?
FAQs.answer: Yes; users can program narrower or extended ranges in the tune method or sequence to optimize duty cycle.

FAQs.question: What are the common values used for this parameter?
FAQs.answer: Proteomics often uses 350–1800 m/z, metabolomics 70–1000 m/z; calibration uses set points across 138–1822 m/z.

FAQs.question: Are there any known issues with this parameter?
FAQs.answer: At very low m/z (<50) ion optics transmission drops, and at >2000 high-mass ions may suffer reduced trapping efficiency.

description: In normal full-scan mode the LTQ XL collects spectra at approximately 16 700 amu s⁻¹, while TurboScan reaches up to 125 000 amu s⁻¹, supporting rapid chromatography and data-dependent workflows.
prompt: State the range of scan speeds (amu per second) available on the Thermo Finnigan LTQ, distinguishing between Normal, Enhanced and Turbo modes. Return JSON with keys mode and scan_rate_amu_per_s for each mode.

FAQs.question: What is the purpose of this parameter?
FAQs.answer: It indicates how quickly the instrument can acquire a full mass spectrum.

FAQs.question: How does this parameter affect the model's performance?
FAQs.answer: Higher scan speeds capture more data points across narrow chromatographic peaks but may reduce resolving power.

FAQs.question: What are the default values for this parameter?
FAQs.answer: Normal mode (~16 700 amu s⁻¹) is the factory default.

FAQs.question: Can this parameter be adjusted during acquisition?
FAQs.answer: Yes; users select scan rate by choosing Normal, Enhanced, or Turbo in the method.

FAQs.question: What are the common values used for this parameter?
FAQs.answer: Proteomic LC-MS/MS often alternates between Normal and Turbo scans to balance speed and signal-to-noise.

FAQs.question: Are there any known issues with this parameter?
FAQs.answer: Turbo scans can increase electronic noise and reduce mass accuracy if ion statistics are very low.

description: The LTQ offers nominal resolution of 0.7 FWHM across the mass range; Zoom and Ultra-Zoom modes tighten resolution to 0.3 FWHM and 0.15 FWHM respectively, enabling isotopic pattern clarity.
prompt: List the full-width half-maximum (FWHM) resolution values achievable on the LTQ in Normal, Zoom, and Ultra-Zoom modes. Return JSON keys mode and FWHM.

FAQs.question: What is the purpose of this parameter?
FAQs.answer: It specifies how closely two ions with similar m/z can be distinguished.

FAQs.question: How does this parameter affect the model's performance?
FAQs.answer: Higher resolution improves mass accuracy and reduces spectral overlap but can slow scan speed.

FAQs.question: What are the default values for this parameter?
FAQs.answer: 0.7 FWHM is the default in Normal mode.

FAQs.question: Can this parameter be adjusted during acquisition?
FAQs.answer: Yes; method events can call Zoom or Ultra-Zoom scans for specific scan segments.

FAQs.question: What are the common values used for this parameter?
FAQs.answer: Routine LC-MS/MS uses 0.7 FWHM; isotope pattern verification may use 0.3 FWHM.

FAQs.question: Are there any known issues with this parameter?
FAQs.answer: Operating at 0.15 FWHM dramatically decreases ion statistics and scan speed, impacting sensitivity.

description: The system supports Heated Electrospray Ionization (HESI) and Atmospheric Pressure Chemical Ionization (APCI) sources in addition to its standard ESI probe, covering flow rates from nanoliter LC to direct infusion.
prompt: Enumerate the ionization techniques available for the LTQ (ESI, HESI, APCI) and indicate suitable flow-rate ranges. Return JSON with keys technique and recommended_flow_rate_ul_min.

FAQs.question: What is the purpose of this parameter?
FAQs.answer: Determines how analyte molecules are converted into gas-phase ions for analysis.

FAQs.question: How does this parameter affect the model's performance?
FAQs.answer: Choosing the appropriate ionization mode directly impacts sensitivity and ion fragmentation pathways.

FAQs.question: What are the default values for this parameter?
FAQs.answer: The factory configuration ships with an ESI source.

FAQs.question: Can this parameter be adjusted during acquisition?
FAQs.answer: Yes; the physical probe can be swapped and method parameters (spray voltage, vaporizer temp) optimized.

FAQs.question: What are the common values used for this parameter?
FAQs.answer: Proteomics commonly uses HESI at 2 kV spray voltage; small-molecule LC/MS often uses APCI with 4.5 kV corona.

FAQs.question: Are there any known issues with this parameter?
FAQs.answer: APCI can exhibit high chemical background in complex matrices, reducing mass accuracy.

description: Vendor specifications cite sub-ppm concentration detection with limits in the low attomole-to-femtomole range for peptides when using HESI, enabling trace-level quantification.
prompt: Report the limit of detection (LOD) in moles for a standard peptide (e.g., reserpine) on the LTQ using HESI. Return JSON with keys analyte and LOD_mol.

FAQs.question: What is the purpose of this parameter?
FAQs.answer: Indicates the smallest quantity of analyte that can be reliably detected.

FAQs.question: How does this parameter affect the model's performance?
FAQs.answer: Higher sensitivity improves detection of low-abundance species, expanding dynamic range in complex samples.

FAQs.question: What are the default values for this parameter?
FAQs.answer: Specification sheet lists LOD of 125 fg (≈1×10⁻¹⁸ mol) for reserpine.

FAQs.question: Can this parameter be adjusted during acquisition?
FAQs.answer: Indirectly; tuning source conditions, capillary temperature, and gas settings optimizes sensitivity.

FAQs.question: What are the common values used for this parameter?
FAQs.answer: Proteomics methods target attomole-level detection for tryptic peptides.

FAQs.question: Are there any known issues with this parameter?
FAQs.answer: Contamination and matrix effects can suppress signal, masking true sensitivity.

description: The linear ion trap architecture allows data-dependent fragmentation up to MS¹⁰, providing rich structural elucidation for complex molecules.
prompt: Specify the maximum number of sequential fragmentation stages (n) the LTQ supports and typical use-cases for high MSn depth. Return JSON keys max_n and example_applications.

FAQs.question: What is the purpose of this parameter?
FAQs.answer: Indicates how many rounds of fragmentation can be performed on a precursor ion.

FAQs.question: How does this parameter affect the model's performance?
FAQs.answer: Higher MSn depth yields detailed structural information but extends duty-cycle time.

FAQs.question: What are the default values for this parameter?
FAQs.answer: Methods commonly use MS² or MS³; the hardware supports up to MS¹⁰.

FAQs.question: Can this parameter be adjusted during acquisition?
FAQs.answer: Yes; MSn depth is set in the instrument method for each data-dependent event.

FAQs.question: What are the common values used for this parameter?
FAQs.answer: Proteomics uses MS²; metabolite-ID workflows may employ MS⁴ or MS⁵ for structural confirmation.

FAQs.question: Are there any known issues with this parameter?
FAQs.answer: Extended MSn reduces total cycle speed, lowering overall spectral sampling.

description: The LTQ transitions between positive and negative ion modes in less than 100 ms, enabling fast polarity switching within a single chromatographic run.
prompt: Provide the measured time required for the LTQ to switch between positive and negative polarity. Return JSON key switching_time_ms.

FAQs.question: What is the purpose of this parameter?
FAQs.answer: It determines how quickly the instrument can alternate polarity to detect oppositely charged species.

FAQs.question: How does this parameter affect the model's performance?
FAQs.answer: Faster switching minimizes data loss during fast LC gradients that require both polarities.

FAQs.question: What are the default values for this parameter?
FAQs.answer: <100 ms according to manufacturer.

FAQs.question: Can this parameter be adjusted during acquisition?
FAQs.answer: No; it is hardware-defined, but the user decides where to place polarity-switching events.

FAQs.question: What are the common values used for this parameter?
FAQs.answer: Most methods employ polarity switching every other scan (~1 s) to balance duty cycle.

FAQs.question: Are there any known issues with this parameter?
FAQs.answer: Rapid switching can momentarily destabilize the spray, causing signal dips.

description: The instrument maintains linear response across more than a 4 000-fold concentration range within a single scan, supporting quantitative assays without signal saturation.
prompt: State the dynamic range (ratio) achievable in a single scan on the LTQ. Return JSON key dynamic_range.

FAQs.question: What is the purpose of this parameter?
FAQs.answer: Indicates the range of ion intensities the instrument can measure accurately in one scan.

FAQs.question: How does this parameter affect the model's performance?
FAQs.answer: A wide dynamic range allows simultaneous detection of high- and low-abundance species.

FAQs.question: What are the default values for this parameter?
FAQs.answer: Specification lists >4 000:1 within a single scan.

FAQs.question: Can this parameter be adjusted during acquisition?
FAQs.answer: Not directly; dynamic range is inherent to the detector and ion-trap capacity.

FAQs.question: What are the common values used for this parameter?
FAQs.answer: Quantitative workflows assume linearity across at least 3 orders of magnitude.

FAQs.question: Are there any known issues with this parameter?
FAQs.answer: Very high ion counts may lead to space-charge effects, compressing the dynamic range.

description: Approximate footprint is 42 cm × 34 cm × 51 cm (16.5 in × 13.4 in × 20.1 in), allowing the LTQ to fit comfortably on a standard laboratory bench with space for ancillary pumps.
prompt: Provide the external dimensions (width, depth, height) of the LTQ chassis in centimeters and inches. Return JSON keys cm and inches as arrays.

FAQs.question: What is the purpose of this parameter?
FAQs.answer: Determines the bench space required for installation.

FAQs.question: How does this parameter affect the model's performance?
FAQs.answer: It does not affect performance but impacts laboratory layout and ergonomics.

FAQs.question: What are the default values for this parameter?
FAQs.answer: See specification above.

FAQs.question: Can this parameter be adjusted during acquisition?
FAQs.answer: No; it is a fixed physical property.

FAQs.question: What are the common values used for this parameter?
FAQs.answer: Most units share the same chassis; variants differ by only a few centimeters.

FAQs.question: Are there any known issues with this parameter?
FAQs.answer: Adequate clearance (>10 cm) is required around the vents to prevent overheating.

description: The LTQ mass spectrometer weighs approximately 143 kg (315 lb); listings that include additional vacuum accessories report up to 177 kg.
prompt: State the shipping weight of the LTQ instrument in kilograms and pounds. Return JSON keys kg and lb.

FAQs.question: What is the purpose of this parameter?
FAQs.answer: Informs shipping, rigging, and bench-load considerations.

FAQs.question: How does this parameter affect the model's performance?
FAQs.answer: It does not directly affect performance but influences vibrational stability.

FAQs.question: What are the default values for this parameter?
FAQs.answer: ~143 kg without external pumps.

FAQs.question: Can this parameter be adjusted during acquisition?
FAQs.answer: No.

FAQs.question: What are the common values used for this parameter?
FAQs.answer: Units typically range 140–177 kg depending on configuration.

FAQs.question: Are there any known issues with this parameter?
FAQs.answer: Floor loading must be verified for upper-level labs.
